title: Energy-Latency Attacks to On-Device Neural Networks via Sponge Poisoning. (arXiv:2305.03888v1 [cs.CR])
abstract: In recent years, on-device deep learning has gained attention as a means of developing affordable deep learning applications for mobile devices. However, on-device models are constrained by limited energy and computation resources. In the mean time, a poisoning attack known as sponge poisoning has been developed.This attack involves feeding the model with poisoned examples to increase the energy consumption during inference. As previous work is focusing on server hardware accelerators, in this work, we extend the sponge poisoning attack to an on-device scenario to evaluate the vulnerability of mobile device processors. We present an on-device sponge poisoning attack pipeline to simulate the streaming and consistent inference scenario to bridge the knowledge gap in the on-device setting. Our exclusive experimental analysis with processors and on-device networks shows that sponge poisoning attacks can effectively pollute the modern processor with its built-in accelerator. We analyze the

Title: Energy-Latency Attacks to On-Device Neural Networks via Sponge Poisoning. (arXiv:2305.03888v1 [cs.CR])
Abstract: In recent years, on-device deep learning has gained attention as a means of developing affordable deep learning applications for mobile devices. However, on-device models are constrained by limited energy and computation resources. In the mean time, a poisoning attack known as sponge poisoning has been developed.This attack involves feeding the model with poisoned examples to increase the energy consumption during inference. As previous work is focusing on server hardware accelerators, in this work, we extend the sponge poisoning attack to an on-device scenario to evaluate the vulnerability of mobile device processors. We present an on-device sponge poisoning attack pipeline to simulate the streaming and consistent inference scenario to bridge the knowledge gap in the on-device setting. Our exclusive experimental analysis with processors and on-device networks shows that sponge poisoning attacks can effectively pollute the modern processor with its built-in accelerator. translated_title: 通过Sponge毒化对设备上神经网络进行能量延迟攻击
translated_abstract: 近年来，设备上的深度学习因其开发移动设备上的经济实惠深度学习应用而备受关注。然而，设备上的模型受到有限的能量和计算资源的约束。同时，一种名为Sponge毒化的攻击方式已经被开发出来。这种攻击方式涉及到提供毒害样本给模型，以增加推断期间的能量消耗。由于先前的工作侧重于服务器硬件加速器，因此在本文中，我们将Sponge毒化攻击扩展到设备上的情况，以评估移动设备处理器的安全性。我们提出了一个设备上的Sponge毒化攻击流程，以模拟流式和一致的推断场景，以填补设备上设置中的知识差距。我们在处理器和设备网络方面进行了独家实验分析，结果显示Sponge毒化攻击可以有效污染具有内置加速器的现代处理器。我们分析了在设备上进行神经网络毒化攻击的能量和延迟成本。
tldr: 本研究针对移动设备处理器的安全性，提出了一种设备上的Sponge毒化攻击流程，可以有效地污染具有内置加速器的现代处理器，同时分析了毒化攻击的能量和延迟成本。
en_tdlr: This study proposes an on-device Sponge poisoning attack pipeline to evaluate the vulnerability of mobile device processors, which can effectively pollute modern processors with built-in accelerators. Additionally, the energy and latency costs of poisoning attacks are analyzed.
